Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Endoscopic Pedicle Saphenous Vein Graft Harvesting in Coronary Artery Bypass Grafting

Trial_Design.evidence: Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence

Participants.evidence: Participants were patients undergoing coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) with SVGs. Eligibility criteria excluded patients with severe diabetes, age ≥80, and those requiring multivessel bypass.

Intervention.evidence: The intervention group underwent Pedicle-EVH, while the control group received conventional NT-SVG harvesting.

Objective.evidence: This study aims to assess the effectiveness of endoscopic pedicle SVG harvesting (Pedicle-EVH) in reducing wound complications while maintaining graft patency.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was early graft patency, assessed via coronary computed tomographic angiography (CCTA) before hospital discharge.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence, with allocation concealment via sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was not applied to patients or clinicians.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 148 patients were randomised: 72 to Pedicle-EVH and 76 to NT-SVG.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Early patency was 95.8% in the Pedicle-EVH group, with 69 out of 72 patients showing patent grafts.

Harms.evidence: No major wound complications were reported in the Pedicle-EVH group, while lymphorrhea occurred in 2/72 (2.8%) patients.

Funding.evidence: The authors declare no conflicts of interest.
